concept.title: Trimming Exeter paper for common Kodak roll sizes

conbody.p: Exeter paper, highly recommended for making custom film backing paper, is available in a 26" width and 25' minimum length from Cartoon Colour, an animation graphics supply store: http://www.cartooncolour.com/catalog/product_info.php?products_id=302

This is what Exeter paper looks like, here cut down to a 118 spool: a thin, somewhat fold-resistant paper with a glossy back and matte inside (relative to the natural curl). I have not tested its opacity--if the winding window were left facing the sun for several hours in a back seat, you might get some fog, so I advise covering the winding window between advances unless you use the roll relatively quickly.

At the 25 ft. minimum length that you can order it, you can cut many dozens of odd-sized backing papers from the stuff. You'll want to cut a length that is common to one or more sizes that you want to prepare, then use a pivoted-arm paper cutter to trim each strip, using 4-5 progressive cuts along the length. I used cardboard strips, measured in advance to fit the spools, to pre-set the offset for a very stiff strip of cardboard that I taped down as a long guide on the cutter base. As you cut off strips, I suggest taking a strip alternately off each long side so that any cutting mistakes accumulate only halfway across.
